data.subject: RS
data.title: Monsters and Magic in Japanese Popular Culture
data.description: An examination of the roles played by monsters, magic, and supernatural creatures in Japanese popular culture, with attention to their treatment in Buddhism, Shinto, Daoism, and folk practices. Topics include modern-day creations such as Godzilla and Pokemon and traditional beings such as deities, ghosts, angry spirits, goblins, and shapeshifters.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sacred Beauty: Religion and the Arts
data.description: An exploration of the spiritual dimension through the medium of art, sacred and secular. Aspects of the quest for meaning in world religions, expressed variously in the visual arts, architecture, music, and the cinema will be considered.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 122. This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Christianity and Social Change in Canada
data.description: How has Christianity been a force for both oppression and liberation in Canada's history? This course examines the involvement of Christianity in such Canadian matters as racism, colonization, and the creation of the social welfare state.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religions of Asia
data.description: An introduction to religious traditions of Asia, including Hinduism, Buddhism, and East Asian traditions. Further topics may include Sikhism, Jainism, and Shinto.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religions of the West
data.description: Encounter with Judaism, Christianity, and Islam: the characteristics and interaction of the three major religious traditions originating in the Middle East that have shaped the image of the Western World.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Evil
data.description: How do the religions of the world define evil? How do they suggest it can be overcome? Classical and modern writers from Judaism, Christianity, Buddhism, and Hinduism will be considered.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sacred Beauty: Religion and the Arts
data.description: An exploration of the spiritual dimension through the medium of art, sacred and secular. Aspects of the quest for meaning in world religions, expressed variously in the visual arts, architecture, music, and the cinema will be considered.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 122. This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: What is Religion?
data.description: Using examples drawn from world religions, new religious movements, indigenous religious traditions, and popular culture, this course introduces students to religion as a human and social phenomenon.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Big Ideas of the Bible
data.description: The Bible is the most translated and most read document in human history. This course explores central biblical ideas, from creation to the end of time, violence to redemption, and political intrigue to family ties, and examines their impact on Judaism, Christianity, and Western Culture.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Christian Ethics
data.description: An introduction to Christian ethical theory and practice and their implications for personal and social living. Case studies will investigate sexual morality, business and medical ethics, environmental issues, violence and non-violence, and family life.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Roman Catholicism
data.description: An introduction to the significance of Catholic beliefs, values, and practices for our time. Topics include spirituality, ethics, the meaning of the sacraments, prayer, sin and salvation, questions of authority, tradition, and change, and the role of women.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Introduction to Christian Theology
data.description: Introduction to the classical themes of Christian theology (revelation, God, creation, sin, Jesus Christ, salvation, church, etc.) and their interrelationship, critical reflection on these beliefs, and examination of debates about the meaning of Christian beliefs in contemporary contexts.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion and Popular Culture
data.description: An examination of the role that religion and myth play in popular culture, including television, cinema, music, fashion, and sport.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Love and Friendship
data.description: A study of the significance of love and friendship in classical and contemporary religious writers. We will consider questions such as, 'Why are friendship and love important for human living?' and 'Is friendship with God a possibility?'
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sikhism
data.description: An exploration of the origins and development of Sikhism, the Guru institution, scripture, ritual, and gender from an historical and contemporary perspective. Issues facing Sikhs in Canada and other countries will also be examined.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Hinduism
data.description: A study of the development of religious thought in India from the Vedic Period to the present. The course will combine an historical survey with a study of representative texts from the religious, philosophical, social, and political thought of the Hindus.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Buddhism
data.description: An introduction to the unifying beliefs and philosophical presuppositions of the Buddhist world-view, and an overview of the diverse forms of Buddhism in South and South-East Asia, Tibet, China, and Japan.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Buddhism in Tibet
data.description: The history of Buddhism's expansion into Tibet, its doctrines and practices, including the institution of the Dalai Lama and the 'Tibetan Book of the Dead', and the practice of Buddhism outside Tibet since 1959.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Islam
data.description: An introduction to the Islamic faith and practice, with a review of the development, achievements, and impact of the Muslim community from Muhammad the Prophet to the present day.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Islam in North America
data.description: An examination of Islam in North America. Topics include basic beliefs and practices, history, Muslim diversity, everyday life, relations with other religions and peoples, contributions to North American culture, and depictions of Islam in popular culture.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills the Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion in America
data.description: The course examines religion in the American context regarding issues like secularization, the nature and the influence of sects (e.g., Mormonism, Pentecostalism), Protestant revivalism and televangelism, and the impact of non-Christian traditions (e.g., Buddhism, Islam).
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: World Religions and Politics
data.description: How have religions influenced and been influenced by politics? How do the world's major religions understand political institutions and theories? Important writers from the world religions will be placed in dialogue with classical and modern thinkers.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Global Religious Fundamentalism
data.description: This course examines the varieties of religious fundamentalism around the world and how religious fundamentalism emerges and can become a motivating factor in ethno-nationalism, inter-religious conflict, and international affairs.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sacred Places
data.description: From Mecca to Benares, Stonehenge to Chartres - a consideration of sacred cities, shrines, rivers, mountains, worship centres, and other places which have inspired the spiritual imagination of individuals and communities within various religious traditions.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sacred Words and Sacred Texts
data.description: An exploration of the role of scripture/sacred texts in religious traditions and a study of representative texts and interpretations. This course will include an examination of the oral, meditative, and artistic use of scripture/sacred texts and sacred words.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Jesus: Life and Legacy
data.description: The life and death of Jesus of Nazareth, as experienced and interpreted by his followers and recorded in the New Testament and other ancient literature. Attention is given to Jesus' identity as a Jew in the Roman Empire in the first century, his teachings and actions, and his ongoing significance throughout history.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Insiders and Outsiders in the Bible
data.description: This course explores the tension between insiders and outsiders in the Bible, examining the rationale for and implications of issues such as purity, holy war, the chosen people, and the Gentiles.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: The Anglican Tradition
data.description: An examination of the Anglican tradition from its beginnings to the present. This course will examine the ecclesial, liturgical, theological, and ethical dimensions of the tradition with special attention to its Canadian forms.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 2B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: History of Christian Thought
data.description: An analysis of the major theological developments in the Christian traditions from the apostolic era to the present.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Catholic Social Thought
data.description: This course will explore the origins, development, and contemporary challenges to Catholic social thought. The main focus will be on the critical and global influences of the past 100 years.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Responses to Political Oppression
data.description: An examination of the Christian responses to regimes of political oppression in the 20th century. Topics include the Nazi Holocaust, Latin American liberation theologies, and Apartheid.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Women and the Church
data.description: A multi-disciplinary examination of the evolution of the relationship between women and the church in the Christian tradition.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Christian Sexual Ethics
data.description: Historical and contemporary Christian approaches to ethical questions about human sexuality and relationships. Topics include marriage, celibacy, single life, homosexuality, HIV/AIDS, sexual violence, gender roles, abortion, reproductive technologies, and sexuality and spirituality.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Gospel and Liberation
data.description: A multi-disciplinary study of the Christian gospel as a means to liberation in Canadian society; its roles in the theory and practice of liberation theologies; and the role of contemplation and action in political and spiritual life.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Eastern Christianity: Being God and Human
data.description: Specific topics include sin, deification, divinity, human transformation, church structure, and the nature of community.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: God
data.description: An examination of ideas about God in Western thought from religious, philosophical, cultural, scientific, and political perspectives.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: How to Study Religion
data.description: An exploration of the nature of religion through: 1) the history of the study of religion, 2) exposure to varying methods and ways of approaching religious phenomena, and 3) consideration of accounts of religious experience.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion in Sociological Perspective
data.description: An examination of the nature of religious experience, the elements of religious group life, and the ways in which religions are a source of social stability and peace as well as of social change and conflict.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion and the Media
data.description: An examination of the coverage of religion in print journalism, news broadcasting, and radio and television documentaries. Topics include secular versus confessional coverage, the politics of religious reportage, televangelism, cults, and current ethical issues.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Cults and New Religious Movements
data.description: This course examines various cults and new religious movements (e.g., Scientology, Krishna Consciousness, Neo-paganism) and places them within the context of our sociological knowledge of their emergence, who joins and why, and other issues.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Millennialism & Violence
data.description: An examination of the nature and causes of episodes of mass violence inspired by apocalyptic beliefs. This course will use historical and contemporary case studies and theoretical discussions of the social and psychological factors precipitating violence.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Christian Fundamentalism
data.description: A social scientific and historical examination of Christian fundamentalism in Canada and the United States. Topics include right-wing politics and religion, ideology, culture and identity, sexual morality, gender, and race.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Current Ethical Issues
data.description: An examination of specific current individual and social problems such as human sexuality, social justice, urban decay, and human rights, in the light of Christian moral consciousness.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Women and the Great Religions
data.description: Through a review of the teachings of the great religious traditions about women, this course aims to arrive at a global view of the situation of women "in the world of religion". On the basis of the evidence gathered, it will attempt an estimation of the role of religion as an intimate and important influence on human development.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Spirit in Motion: Secular and Religious Spiritualities Today
data.description: Exploring changes in spirituality in modern society. Topics include the impact of eastern religions, new cults and sects, healing, psychology, ecological spirituality, women and spirituality, and the spiritual practices of aboriginal peoples on traditional concepts of spirituality.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Special Topics
data.description: Consult Department for current offerings.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Images of the Feminine: India
data.description: This course offers an in-depth study and analysis of women as well as the Divine Feminine in the religions of India, which include Hinduism, Islam, Sikhism, Buddhism, Jainism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, tribal religion, and the Baha'i tradition.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Gender and Asian Religions
data.description: This course focuses on how the major Asian religious traditions construct gender and legitimize certain gender roles. Traditions covered include Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, Islam, and Shinto.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Zen and Now: History and Influence of Zen
data.description: An historical examination of the development of Zen in China and Japan and its influence on the development of Buddhism in the West.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills the Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Islam and Christianity
data.description: A survey of the history of the Muslim-Christian relations from the time of the emergence of Islam to the present, with a special emphasis on the characteristic polemic literature which each community produced against the other.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Canadian Native Religious Traditions
data.description: An examination of the ritual and oral traditions of a specific pre-modern group of native peoples to discern their attempts to integrate themselves and their environment.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors. Taught at Laurier as RE 318]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion in Canada
data.description: Religion in Canada past and present. Topics include Canada's Christian origins, religion and nationalism in English and French Canada, secularization, religious tolerance and multiculturalism, Christian antisemitism, Buddhism, Hinduism, and the Sikh communities, and new religious movements.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: East Comes West, West Turns East
data.description: The immigration of Asian peoples to Canada has brought varied religious traditions. This course will examine the development of these religions in Canada, their transformation within the Canadian context, and their adoption outside of the Asian cultural and religious milieu.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Women in Buddhism: A Global Perspective
data.description: An examination of the interplay between cultural and historical contexts and beliefs about the religious potential of Buddhist women, and their consequences for women's religious practice historically and currently in India, China, Japan and the West.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills the Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Interreligious Encounter and Dialogue
data.description: A study of the encounter and dialogue of men and women of different faiths, emphasizing movements, figures and ideas central to the contemporary scene. Both bilateral, for example Christian-Buddhist, and multilateral developments will be explored.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Ethics and Global Politics
data.description: An examination of the role of religious ethics, as understood by the major world religions, in international affairs. Selected cases of recent international conflict, international terrorism, and humanitarian intervention will be covered.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Perspectives on Marriage and Family
data.description: This course examines how the world religions understand family relations in various social, cultural, and political contexts.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sex and the World Religions
data.description: This course examines deeply rooted attitudes in the major world religions toward sexual identity, practices, and gender. Examining sacred scriptures and codes of conduct from the world religions, as well as fictional writings and films, this course enables students to explore various social and religious traditions.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Global Christianity
data.description: This course examines the scope and character of contemporary Christianity around the globe, especially its diversity of expression and varied interactions with culture.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: The Body, Dress, and Religion
data.description: From clothing to hairstyles to tattoos, dress can express beliefs, aspects of identity, and power. This course examines dress in a variety of religions from ancient Greece to the modern era. The course includes attention to the look and feel of dress on the body, conflicts that can arise over dress and religion, as well as the role of dress in the formation and maintenance of religious communities.
data.notes: [Note: The course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Selected Topics in Biblical Studies
data.description: Consult Department for current offerings.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 307]

data.subject: RS
data.title: The Bible and Peace
data.description: An examination of diverse biblical views of peace in relation to war, justice, and salvation with attention to their relevance for the contemporary quest for peace.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Seeking Wisdom in the Bible
data.description: This course explores the theme of wisdom in the Bible and related literature in the period from ancient Israel to the first century CE. It examines the varied cultural influences on biblical wisdom traditions.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Vatican II
data.description: An analysis of the context and rich documentary tradition of the second Vatican Council, the course will explore, in particular, the global dynamics of these teachings.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Modern Christian Thought
data.description: A biographical and thematic approach to the study of the major nineteenth-century thinkers who shaped modern theology. Among theologians and issues to be considered are Schleiermacher and liberalism, Kierkegaard and existentialism, Troeltsch and historicism.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Contemporary Christian Thought
data.description: An examination of how Christian beliefs and practices have been reinterpreted by representative Christian theologians to address the challenges of the 20th and 21st centuries.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Shapers of the Roman Catholic Tradition
data.description: An examination of some influential Christian thinkers who have played a critical role in Roman Catholic theology such as Augustine, Hildegard of Bingen, Julian of Norwich, Aquinas, Newman, Rahner, Ruether, Schussler Fiorenza, Lonergan.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Christian Feminist Thought
data.description: Christian feminist thought challenges traditional Christian teaching at every level. This course will explore in particular the challenges to traditional disciplines of theology and spirituality.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Atheism, Skepticism, and Free Thought
data.description: This course considers the social history of atheism, skepticism, and free thought in the context of religious debate in the West. It covers the period from the 19th century to the present.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Quests
data.description: Profiles, biographies, and autobiographies of individuals in search of ultimate meaning. Persons studied are spiritual seekers from all walks of life: traditional religious figures, artists, novelists, scientists, and others.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Icons in Eastern Christianity: Windows to Heaven
data.description: In the Christian East, icons are seen as theology in colour. They are known as "windows to heaven". Icons both reflect and help form Christian teaching. This course investigates the development of iconography, how icons are understood within the tradition, and how other approaches to the aesthetic can inform a contemporary understanding of iconography.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Perspectives on the Environmental Crisis
data.description: An examination of religious perspectives on the environmental crisis, including an analysis of what the various religious traditions have taught about caring for the created universe. Special attention will be given to the views of the native peoples of Canada on responsibility for the creation, and to religious resources for developing an ethical stance on environmental issues and a respect for nature.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Bioethics and Religious Values
data.description: This course will study issues such as sexual ethics, eugenics, euthanasia, suicide, genetic screening, organ transplants, organ and embryo banking, as they stand in relation to traditional religious values.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Justice, Peace, and Development
data.description: An examination of communities, movements, and theologies which express a Christian hope for justice, peace, and development in the encounter with injustice, oppression, and poverty.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Special Topics
data.description: See Department for current offerings.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Study-Travel Seminar in Religion
data.description: Consult Department for current offerings.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 369]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Directed Readings in Special Subjects
data.description: Readings in selected topics chosen in discussion with instructor.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sociology of Religion
data.description: This course examines key substantive, theoretical, and methodological issues of the sociology of religion through the detailed study of important classical and contemporary works in the field.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Religious Studies majors
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion, Science, and Technology
data.description: This course studies the interactions between religion, science, and technology as well as their implications for knowledge, values, authority, and ethics.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Special Topics
data.description: Consult the department for special topics.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 400.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Study Term Abroad
data.description: Consult the department for current offerings.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 450]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Directed Readings in Special Subjects
data.description: Readings in selected topics chosen in discussion with instructor.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Senior Seminar
data.description: This seminar examines contemporary methods and theories in the study of religion and how they may be used to address specific themes in religious studies.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Honours Religious Studies

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Diversity in North America
data.description: An examination of historical forces and other factors that have shaped religious diversity in North America.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Case Studies in Religion
data.description: Case studies focused on lived religions in their cultural settings.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Directed Study
data.description: Individual study of a topic under the guidance of a member of the program.  Directed Study topics must be approved by the director.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Special Topics
data.description: Group study of a topic under the guidance of a member of the program.

data.subject: RS
data.title: History of Religion in North America
data.description: This course examines the history of varius religions and religious phenomena in North America, with attention to such factors as colonization, immigration, gender, race, class, theology, and praxis.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Approaches to the Study of Religion in North America
data.description: A consideration of the theories, methods, and interpretations that have been influential in the study of religion in North America.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sociology of Religion
data.description: The course examines key substantive, theoretical and methodological issues of the sociology of religion through the detailed study of important classical and contemporary works in the field. Representative issues addressed are: the social and psychological nature and function of religious experience, the character of conversion processes, the social and political implications of religious ideologies and organizations, the status of religious beliefs and practices in an age of seeming secularization. Attention will be given to both western and non-western religious traditions as well as to both established and newer forms of religious life.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Millennialism & Violence
data.description: An examination of the nature and causes of episodes of mass violence inspired by apocalyptic beliefs. This course will use historical and contemporary case studies and theoretical discussions of the social and psychological factors precipitating violence.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion in Sociological Perspective
data.description: An examination of the nature of religious experience, the elements of religious group life, and the ways in which religions are a source of social stability and peace as well as of social change and conflict.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion in America
data.description: The course examines religion in the American context regarding issues like secularization, the nature and the influence of sects (e.g., Mormonism, Pentecostalism), Protestant revivalism and televangelism, and the impact of non-Christian traditions (e.g., Buddhism, Islam).
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Cults and New Religious Movements
data.description: This course examines various cults and new religious movements (e.g., Scientology, Krishna Consciousness, Neo-paganism) and places them within the context of our sociological knowledge of their emergence, who joins and why, and other issues.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sociology of Religion
data.description: This course examines key substantive, theoretical, and methodological issues of the sociology of religion through the detailed study of important classical and contemporary works in the field.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Religious Studies majors
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sociology of Religion
data.description: The course examines key substantive, theoretical and methodological issues of the sociology of religion through the detailed study of important classical and contemporary works in the field. Representative issues addressed are: the social and psychological nature and function of religious experience, the character of conversion processes, the social and political implications of religious ideologies and organizations, the status of religious beliefs and practices in an age of seeming secularization. Attention will be given to both western and non-western religious traditions as well as to both established and newer forms of religious life.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Women and the Great Religions
data.description: Through a review of the teachings of the great religious traditions about women, this course aims to arrive at a global view of the situation of women "in the world of religion". On the basis of the evidence gathered, it will attempt an estimation of the role of religion as an intimate and important influence on human development.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sex and the World Religions
data.description: This course examines deeply rooted attitudes in the major world religions toward sexual identity, practices, and gender. Examining sacred scriptures and codes of conduct from the world religions, as well as fictional writings and films, this course enables students to explore various social and religious traditions.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Women in Buddhism: A Global Perspective
data.description: An examination of the interplay between cultural and historical contexts and beliefs about the religious potential of Buddhist women, and their consequences for women's religious practice historically and currently in India, China, Japan and the West.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills the Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Images of the Feminine: India
data.description: This course offers an in-depth study and analysis of women as well as the Divine Feminine in the religions of India, which include Hinduism, Islam, Sikhism, Buddhism, Jainism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, tribal religion, and the Baha'i tradition.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Gender and Asian Religions
data.description: This course focuses on how the major Asian religious traditions construct gender and legitimize certain gender roles. Traditions covered include Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, Islam, and Shinto.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Biblical Studies 1
data.description: A survey of the literature, history, and religious thought of the Old Testament as seen in its cultural setting in the ancient Near East.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Biblical Studies 2
data.description: A survey of the literature, history, and religious thought of the New Testament as seen in its cultural setting in the Greco-Roman world.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Death and Dying
data.description: This course examines the ways people of various cultures and religions have thought about death as reflected in their myths, teachings, and science and how they have acted through ritual in the face of death.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Psychology of Religion and Spirituality
data.description: This course examines theories about the psychological nature of religious experience, the source of religious belief, and the religious significance of psychological phenomena. Attention will be given to the role of introspective, psychoanalytic, experimental, humanistic, and transpersonal methods in the psychology of religion.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Personality and Religion
data.description: This course studies the various "developmental tasks" of the human life cycle in order to discover what psychological and religious needs should be satisfied at each stage of a person's life. The course also seeks to develop students' awareness in order to sensitize them to the processes of their own growth and development.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Joan of Arc: Witch, Mystic, Martyr or Saint?
data.description: Using the available historical record as a reference point, this course will examine the many diverse and often contradictory interpretations of the life of Joan of Arc: religious, literary, philosophical, and ethical.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: The Violence of the Bible
data.description: Why has the Bible inspired so much violence? This course explores how the Bible has been used to justify, and to oppose, violence in historical and contemporary contexts. It will address topics such as the crusades, slavery, the "conquest" of the Americas, apartheid in South Africa, the residential school system in Canada, gender violence, and the environmental crisis.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Feminist Approaches to the Bible
data.description: An examination of various feminist approaches to the biblical text including consideration of the impact of sexism and patriarchal structures on a biblical text as well as various models feminist scholars have employed in biblical interpretation.
data.prerequisites: RS 130 taken after Spring 2008 or (RS 100E and 100F)
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 300. This course fulfills an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Contemporary Mennonite Thought
data.description: A survey of contemporary Mennonite theological debate. The course will focus on some of the central themes of the Anabaptist-Mennonite tradition: adult baptism, separation from the world, biblical authority, peace and nonresistance, discipleship as a way of life.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 2C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Carl Jung's Theory of Religion
data.description: Jung's analysis of the development of the personality through its life cycle, and of the central place which religion holds within the process of maturation. This includes a study of the unconscious, the collective unconscious, dreams, myths, symbols and archetypes; and the implications of Jung's theories for religious thought and therapy.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Dreams in Religious Experience
data.description: The course examines the place of dreams in religious experience from ancient to modern times. Present day advances in understanding dream symbols will be explored, as well as the possibility of incorporating the use of dreams in one's personal religious growth and development.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly RS 370. This course fulfills an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Aging as a Spiritual Journey
data.description: The following existential issues related to the aging process are examined from the perspective of the psychology of religion: identity, belief, actualization, existential anxiety, conversion, individuation, and spirituality.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Spirituality and Psychotherapy
data.description: The course examines the spiritual dimension of the search for meaning, especially at crucial points in life, via the work of Viktor Frankl and the spiritual, philosophic, and psychotherapeutic dynamics he introduced.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Psychology of Religion and Spirituality
data.description: This course examines theories about the psychological nature of religious experience, the source of religious belief, and the religious significance of psychological phenomena. Attention will be given to the role of introspective, psychoanalytic, experimental, humanistic, and transpersonal methods in the psychology of religion.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Personality and Religion
data.description: This course studies the various "developmental tasks" of the human life cycle in order to discover what psychological and religious needs should be satisfied at each stage of a person's life. The course also seeks to develop students' awareness in order to sensitize them to the processes of their own growth and development.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Aging as a Spiritual Journey
data.description: The following existential issues related to the aging process are examined from the perspective of the psychology of religion: identity, belief, actualization, existential anxiety, conversion, individuation, and spirituality.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Spirituality and Psychotherapy
data.description: The course examines the spiritual dimension of the search for meaning, especially at crucial points in life, via the work of Viktor Frankl and the spiritual, philosophic, and psychotherapeutic dynamics he introduced.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Carl Jung's Theory of Religion
data.description: Jung's analysis of the development of the personality through its life cycle, and of the central place which religion holds within the process of maturation. This includes a study of the unconscious, the collective unconscious, dreams, myths, symbols and archetypes; and the implications of Jung's theories for religious thought and therapy.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfills an Area 3A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Big Ideas of the Bible
data.description: The Bible is the most translated and most read document in human history. This course explores central biblical ideas, from creation to the end of time, violence to redemption, and political intrigue to family ties, and examines their impact on Judaism, Christianity, and Western Culture.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Insiders and Outsiders in the Bible
data.description: This course explores the tension between insiders and outsiders in the Bible, examining the rationale for and implications of issues such as purity, holy war, the chosen people, and the Gentiles.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Seeking Wisdom in the Bible
data.description: This course explores the theme of wisdom in the Bible and related literature in the period from ancient Israel to the first century CE. It examines the varied cultural influences on biblical wisdom traditions.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 2A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Muslim Lives and Practices Worldwide
data.description: This course examines the diversity of Muslim lives and practices worldwide. Selected case studies raise issues such as gender, authority, stereotypes, fundamentalism, and secularism.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Sex, Politics, and Religion in the U.S. and Canada
data.description: What are the three topics that should not be talked about in polite company? Sex, politics, and religion. Breaking the taboo, this course examines religious practices and conflicts around sexuality and sexual behaviour in the United States and Canada, and how they have manifested in political contests and public policy.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1B requirement for Religious Studies majors].

data.subject: RS
data.title: Buddhism in North America
data.description: This course examines the history and development of Buddhism in North America. Topics such as the adaptation of traditional Buddhism to North American culture and its development as a Western religion will be examined.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: The Body, Dress, and Religion
data.description: From clothing to hairstyles to tattoos, dress can express beliefs, aspects of identity, and power. This course examines dress in a variety of religions from ancient Greece to the modern era. The course includes attention to the look and feel of dress on the body, conflicts that can arise over dress and religion, as well as the role of dress in the formation and maintenance of religious communities.
data.notes: [Note: The course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Monsters and Magic in Japanese Popular Culture
data.description: An examination of the roles played by monsters, magic, and supernatural creatures in Japanese popular culture, with attention to their treatment in Buddhism, Shinto, Daoism, and folk practices. Topics include modern-day creations such as Godzilla and Pokemon and traditional beings such as deities, ghosts, angry spirits, goblins, and shapeshifters.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1A requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Death and Dying
data.description: Death is more than a physical event. It also has legal, social, cultural, psychological, and religious significance. This course examines views about dying, death, and death rituals in several Western and Eastern religions, as well as in some indigenous spiritualities.
data.notes: [Note: The course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion & War: The Language and Imagery of War within Islam, Christianity, and Judaism
data.description: This course explores the phenomena of militant words and images within Islam, Christianity, and Judaism. Considered in conversation with one another, these Abrahamic traditions challenge students to consider the interconnectedness of these communities, histories, and textual traditions.
data.prerequisites: SI 121R or RS 216; Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion & War: The Language and Imagery of War within Islam, Christianity, and Judaism
data.description: This course explores the phenomena of militant words and images within Islam, Christianity, and Judaism. Considered in conversation with one another, these Abrahamic traditions challenge students to consider the interconnectedness of these communities, histories, and textual traditions.
data.prerequisites: SI 121R or RS 216; Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 1C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Diversity and Social Development
data.description: Religious traditions and beliefs contribute both positively and negatively to social development. This course explores the interrelationship of religious diversity, multiculturalism, and attitudes towards social issues.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Gender, Sexuality, and Christianity
data.description: What do the churches say about sex and gender? This course examines how matters of the body have affected Christian spirituality, particularly in the lives of women and LGBTQ persons.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religion Online
data.description: How do people find spirituality on the Internet? This course examines how believers and seekers practice religion online and use the Internet to promote religious belief. The course considers the emergence of online religions, as well as prospects for the future of faith and spirituality online.
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3C requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: RS
data.title: Engaged Buddhism
data.description: This course examines Buddhist - including mindfulness - engagement with contemporary social issues, such as peacemaking, environmentalism, political reform, race and gender concerns, and LGBTQ rights.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Religious Diversity and Social Development
data.description: Religious traditions and beliefs contribute both positively and negatively to social development. This course explores the interrelationship of religious diversity, multiculturalism, and attitudes towards social issues.

data.subject: RS
data.title: Aging and the Spiritual Life
data.description: Engaging experience, theory, and reflection, this course explores spirituality as a central aspect of growth and development in later life. This course draws on perspectives from various faith and humanistic traditions. Topics include religious beliefs and spiritual concerns later in life, a spirituality of aging, providing spiritual care to persons in later life, spirituality and dementia, and death and dying.
data.antirequisites: RS 391 taken Winter 2018; RS 491 Taken Fall 2011 or Fall 2013
data.notes: [Note: This course fulfils an Area 3 requirement for Religious Studies majors.]
